questions.question:
Question 1: The SA Node acts as the pacemaker of the heart because, it  
.
questions.explanation:
The SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart as it generates impulses at the highest rate 
(60-100/min), compared to AV node (40-60/min) and Purkinje fibres (15-40). The impulses 
generated by SA node are conducted through AV node and purkinje fibres repetedly that it will 
prevent AV node or Purkinje fibres reach their own thresholds for self-excitation.

questions.question: Question 2: In which of the following the conduction velocity is least?
questions.explanation:
The conduction velocity is least in AV node. 525 
Sold by @itachibot The slow conduction in the AV node is caused mainly by diminished numbers of gap junctions 
between successive cells in the conducting pathways.

questions.question:
Question 3: The velocity of conduction of impulse is maximum in 
.
questions.explanation:
The velocity of conduction of impulse is maximum in Purkinje fibers. Purkinje fibers have the maximum number of gap junctions hence the maximum conduction 
velocity (4m/s).

questions.question:
Question 4: The AV nodal delay is  
(seconds).
questions.explanation:
The AV nodal delay is 0.1 second. The slow conduction is caused mainly by diminished numbers of gap junctions between 
successive cells in the conducting pathways.It ensures that the atria have ejected their blood into 
the ventricles first before the ventricles contract.

questions.question:
Question 5: If the SA node discharges at 0.00 sec, when will the action potential normally arrive at the 
epicardial surface at the base of the left ventricle?
questions.explanation:
The duration of action potential to arrive at the epicardial surface at the base of the left ventricle is 
0.22sec. Impulse initiated from SA node at 0.00s  Impulse reaches AV node at 0.03s  Delay of impulse at AV node by 0.13s resulting in a total time of 0.16s (0.03+0.13) to reach the 
beginning of Purkinje fibres  Impulse reaches base of Purkinje fibres by 0.03s resulting in a total of time of 0.1˜s (0.16+0.0.3) 
to reach the endocardial surface of the base of the ventricle  Impulse travels from endocardial to epicardial surface in 0.03s (due to arrangement of myocardial 
fibres)  Hence, a total time of 0.22s (0.1˜+0.03) is taken for the impulse to travel from SA node to 
epicardial surface of the base of ventricles 526 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: The order of depolarization after stimulation of Purkinje fibers is:
questions.explanation:
The order of depolarization is from septum  endocardium epicardium. The spread of Cardiac Excitation: Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on 
the AV node. A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the 
ventricles. Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to 
the right across the midportion of the septum. It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV 
groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface. 527 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the 
below image, the action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability? 520 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. Action potential of myocardium: • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte. • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte. • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels. • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+. • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.question: Question 8: Plateau phase of ventricular muscle is due to opening of :
questions.explanation:
Plateau phase of ventricular muscle is due to opening of Ca channel. Action potential of myocardium: • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte. • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte. • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels. • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+. • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase. 528 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Repolarization of cardiac muscle proceeds from:
questions.explanation: Repolarization of cardiac muscle proceeds from epicardium to endocardium. Depolarisation proceeds from endocardium to epicardium in an intact cardiac muscle.

questions.question: Question 10: Phase 0 of pacemaker potential is initiated by:

options.b: Opening of voltage gated Ca2+ channel
options.c: Inactivation of voltage gated Ca2+ channel
options.d: Inactivation of voltage gated Na+ channel

questions.explanation:
Phase 0 of pacemaker potential is initiated by opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. The pacemaker potential consists of: • Phase 0 - this is upstroke seen due to the opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This causes an 
influx of calcium leading to the upstroke. • Phase 3 - This is followed by inactivation of the calcium channels and simultaneous activation of 
K+ channels. This leads to efflux of K+ bringing about repolarization. • Phase 4- As the K+ efflux declines, a channel permeable to both Na+ and K+ opens leading to an 
influx of both Na+ and K+. This is the If channel. This is responsible for slow spontaneous 
diastolic depolarization. This accounts for the automaticity of SA and AV node. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate. Note: Fast voltage-gated Na+ channels seen in myocyte potential are permanently inactivated 
because of the less negative resting potential of the pacemaker cells. 529 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: You are researching the benefits of vagus nerve stimulation as a potential treatment for 
epilepsy. Which of the following parameters can be increased due to vagal stimulation? 521 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Vagal stimulation can cause an increase in the R-R interval in the ECG as it decreases heart rate.

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 13: Einthoven law states that
questions.explanation:
Einthoven's law states Lead I + Lead III = Lead II. Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary formation of three limb leads in a triangle used in 
electrocardiography.

questions.question: Question 14: In Einthoven’s triangle, what is the value of lead III when lead I = 1mV and lead II = 2mV ?
questions.explanation: According to Einthoven's law, Lead I + Lead III=Lead II. Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (2-1) =1 mV.

questions.question:
Question 15: In a standard ECG, an augmented limb lead measures the electrical potential difference 
between: 522 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
531 
Sold by @itachibot In a standard ECG, an augmented lead measures the electrical potential difference between one 
limb and the other two limbs. aVR, aVL, aVF are the augmented limb leads.

questions.question: Question 16: Which part of the ECG corresponds to ventricular repolarization?
questions.explanation:
The part of the ECG that corresponds to ventricular repolarization is T wave. ECG wav

questions.question:
Question 17: The PR interval indicates  
.
questions.explanation:
The PR interval indicates atrial depolarisation(P wave) and AV node conduction time(PR 
segment). PR interval is the time between the beginning of the P wave and the beginning of the QRS 
complex. It is the interval between the beginning of electrical excitation of the atria and the 
beginning of excitation of the ventricles. Normal duration is 0.12-0.20s.

questions.question:
Question 18: The P wave is absent in  
.
questions.explanation:
The P wave is absent in atrial fibrillation. 533 
Sold by @itachibot In atrial fibrillation, numerous small depolarization waves spread in all directions through the 
atria. The waves are weak and many of them are of opposite polarity at any given time, they 
almost electrically neutralize one another. Therefore, P waves are absent from ECG in atrial 
fibrillation.

questions.question: Question 19: The normal mean QRS axis lies between
questions.explanation:
The normal mean QRS axis lies between –30° and +110°. The QRS axis represents the major vector of ventricular activation, which is the overall direction 
of electrical activity.

questions.question:
Question 20: The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by 
.
questions.explanation:
The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by Left stellate ganglion. Innervation of SA Node and AV Node: The SA node develops from structures on the right side of the embryo and the AV node from 
structures on the left.Therefore - ANS

questions.question:
Question 21: You are following up with a patient on a sympathomimetic drug. Which of the following 
effects is unlikely to be due to sympathetic stimulation?
questions.explanation: Sympathetic stimulation causes faster conduction, therefore decreased refractory period. Effects of sympathetic stimulation: • Chronotropic- It increases the rate of sinus nodal discharge. • Dromotropic- It increases the rate of conduction. • Bathmotropic- It increases the level of excitability in all portions of the heart. • Inotropic- It increases the force of contraction of all the cardiac musculature.
